questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with splenomegaly and pancytopenia. Suspecting a hematological malignancy, you prepare a peripheral blood smear, which revealed the findings shown in the given image. These cells were also found to be annexin A1 positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
Hairy cell leukemia
The given peripheral smear shows abnormal B cells with fine hair-like cytoplasmic projections characteristic of hairy cell leukemia.

questions.text: A girl presents with short stature, webbed neck, thick calves, shield-shaped chest, swelling of the ankle, and increased carrying angle. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Turner syndrome

The clinical presentation of short stature, webbed neck, thick calves, shield-shaped chest, swelling of the ankle, and increased carrying angle is suggestive of Turner syndrome.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents with mental retardation and short stature. His parents also say that he is frequently hungry and eats multiple times a day. On examination, truncal obesity and short hands and feet are noted. He has not developed secondary sexual characteristics. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Prader-Willi syndrome

The possible diagnosis is Prader-Willi syndrome, a genomic imprinting disorder. Prader Willi syndrome occurs due to the deletion of band 15q12 on the paternal chromosome and the silencing of the same set of genes derived from maternal chromosomes.

questions.text: A 49-year-old patient comes with complaints of left flank pain, hematuria, weight loss, headache, nausea, and convulsions. A family history of brain tumours and kidney tumours is present. MRI showed a cerebellar mass. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome

The given clinical history of left flank pain, hematuria, weight loss, headache, nausea, and convulsions along with the family history of brain tumours and kidney tumours is suggestive of Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome. (VHL)

questions.text: During rounds, you come across the urinalysis report of the 30-year-old male diagnosed with Fabry’s disease. What type of urinary casts would you expect to see in the report?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Maltese cross cast

Maltese cross urinary casts are seen in a patient diagnosed with Fabry’s disease. Urine analysis in Fabry’s disease may reveal oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarized light showing a maltese cross appearance. It can also be seen in nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: An elderly patient died due to myocardial infarction (MI). Autopsy of the heart shows coagulation necrosis with loss of nuclei and striations along with a brisk interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils. This occurs how many hours after MI?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

1-3 days 

Coagulation necrosis with loss of nuclei and striations along with a brisk interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils is seen in the myocardium 1-3 days after myocardial infarction (MI). The gross appearance of the myocardium at this time will be mottling with a yellow-tan infarct center.

questions.text: A patient is admitted to the hospital with heart failure due to dilated cardiomyopathy. Toxicity by which of the following does not cause this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Selenium

Selenium deficiency (Keshan’s disease) is known to produce dilated cardiomyopathy and not its toxicity.

questions.text: A patient with radiologically confirmed reflux nephropathy develops nephrotic-range proteinuria. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome due to a secondary cause (reflux nephropathy). Secondary nephrotic syndrome in adults is most likely due to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS).

choices.text: Type II and type III hypersensitivity
Type II and type IV hypersensitivity

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is admitted with fever and polyarthritis. He had a bout of streptococcal sore throat infection two weeks back. His ESR on admission was 80mm/hr and fever 39°C. What is the mechanism of tissue injury in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Type II hypersensitivity

The given clinical scenario with polyarthritis (1 major) along with fever and ESR elevated (2 minor) is suggestive of acute rheumatic fever. It is an example of type II hypersensitivity.

questions.text: A 28-year old man presents to the clinic with complaints of lower back pain and passing dark red-colored urine. He was diagnosed with malaria and is on antimalarials for the past 3 days. The peripheral smear of the patient is shown below. What is the mode of inheritance of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
 
The given scenario is suggestive of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. It is the most common enzyme deficiency in humans, inherited as an X-linked recessive disorder. The gene that codes for G6PD is located in the distal long arm of the X chromosome at the Xq28 locus. The inheritance pattern is similar to that of hemophilia and color blindness, where males usually manifest the abnormality and females are carriers.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and macroorchidism. Cytogenetic analysis reveals an expanded CGG repeat in the FMR1 gene. Which of the following genetic disorders is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
 
Intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and macroorchidism, along with an expanded CGG repeat in the FMR1 gene on cytogenetic analysis, is consistent with Fragile X syndrome.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child abruptly develops malaise, fever, nausea, oliguria, and smoky, cola-colored urine 2 weeks after recovery from a sore throat. He is found to have periorbital edema and mild hypertension. Urine examination shows dysmorphic red cells and red cell casts in the urine with mild proteinuria. Which type of hypersensitivity is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephritic syndrome due to post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. This is an example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain, hepatosplenomegaly and WBC count >50,000/mm3. Which of the following genes is involved in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

t (9:22)

The clinical scenario of abdominal pain, hepatosplenomegaly, a TLC of > 50,000/mm³ points toward the diagnosis of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) which results from reciprocal translocation t(9:22) forming the BCR- ABL fusion gene.

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic smoker presents with weight loss, hemoptysis and TTF-1 positivity. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Adenocarcinoma

The clinical scenario cough, hemoptysis, weight loss with image showing immunohistochemical marker thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) positivity is suggestive of adenocarcinoma of the lung.

questions.text: A COPD patient with a history of smoking presents with respiratory symptoms. High resolution CT showed panacinar emphysema. Which enzyme deficiency is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Alpha-1 antitrypsin

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is associated with panacinar emphysema. Panacinar or panlobular emphysema is associated with a1 antitrypsin (a1AT) deficiency. It is exacerbated by smoking. Panacinar occurs more commonly in lower zones and the anterior margins of the lung. In this type, the acini from respiratory bronchiole to terminal blind alveoli are uniformly enlarged.

questions.text: A patient with COPD presented with ARDS symptoms. What is the role of IL-8 in inflammation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Recuritement of neutrophils

IL-8 (CXCL8) is secreted by activated macrophages and endothelial cells which causes activation and recruitment of neutrophils. Once leukocytes have exited the circulation, they move towards the inciting stimulus by chemotaxis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with complaints of persistent headaches. A CT scan of the head reveals a brain tumour. On histopathology, psammoma bodies are seen. Based on these findings, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Meningioma

The clinical vignette and the histopathology showing a tumour with psammoma bodies is suggestive of meningioma. Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumors in adults, typically attached to the dura and arising from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid. They can develop along any external surface of the brain or within the ventricular system, originating from the stromal arachnoid cells of the choroid plexus.

questions.text: A patient Is suffering from a rare disease with mitochondrial inheritance. This can be inherited from which of the following members?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Mother

Diseases with mitochondrial inheritance are inherited exclusively from the affected mother.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever, rash and swelling of her hands and feet since past 5 days. There is desquamative skin rash, oedema of hands and feet, erythema of palms and soles, oral erythema, and cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the likely condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Kawasaki disease

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Kawasaki disease or mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.

questions.text: A patient presented with a painless, well-circumscribed swelling near the wrist joint. There are no skin changes or neurological involvement. Histopathological examination of the swelling revealed spindle cells with palisading of the nuclei as shown in the image below. Which of the following is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Verocay bodies

The given clinical scenario of a painless, well-circumscribed swelling near the wrist joint along with the nuclear-free zones between nuclear palisading observed in the given image is suggestive of schwannoma. Verocay bodies are seen in this condition.
